rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:1
rsbNotes.text:
20:1 preaching the gospel. Jesus was bringing God’s good news at the very time His enemies were plotting against Him.

chief priests . . . scribes . . . elders. This appears to be a delegation from the Sanhedrin.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:2
rsbNotes.text: 20:2 these things. Things such as driving the traders out of the temple.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:3–4
rsbNotes.text: 20:3, 4 Jesus was not avoiding their question. John had testified that Jesus was the Messiah. If they answered Jesus’ question, they would have the answer to their own.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:5–6
rsbNotes.text: 20:5, 6 Notice that they were not concerned with the truth, but with the consequences of their possible answers.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:7–8
rsbNotes.text: 20:7, 8 Jesus will not talk about authority to men who refuse to reply to an important religious question, the answer to which they already know.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:9–12
rsbNotes.text: 20:9–12 The tenants are a vivid picture of the nation that persistently rejected the messengers of God who were sent to call them to repentance.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:13
rsbNotes.text: 20:13 Normally a landowner confronted with persistent refusal to pay and with abuse of his messengers would have taken strong measures. But just as this landowner keeps giving the tenants the opportunity for repentance, so God continues to reach out to sinners.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:14
rsbNotes.text: 20:14 This is the heir. The tenants had refused to acknowledge an owner by paying rent, and they apparently reasoned that with the heir out of the way, they could establish their own title to the land. Jesus is making the point that the nation had behaved outrageously toward God.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:17
rsbNotes.text:
20:17 Jesus quotes Ps. 118:22, which points to a complete reversal of accepted values.

cornerstone. Lit. “the head of the corner.” It may be a large stone in the foundation, laid at the corner and determining the position of two walls. Or it may be the stone at the top of the corner binding the building together.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:19
rsbNotes.text: 20:19 The religious teachers were hostile to Jesus but could find no legal way of harming him.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:20
rsbNotes.text: 20:20 the governor. Clearly the “spies” hoped Jesus would say something that would make the Romans arrest Him.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:21
rsbNotes.text: 20:21 The flattering approach was doubtless meant to put Jesus off guard.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:22
rsbNotes.text: 20:22 Is it lawful. This means “Is it in accordance with God’s law?” (it was required by Roman law). From the point of view of the questioners the answer had to put Jesus at odds with either the Romans or the Jews, who resented the taxes.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 20:24
rsbNotes.text: 20:24 a denarius. Jesus asked for the silver coin that was the proper coinage for paying the tax, roughly equivalent to a day’s wage (15:8 note). It bore an image of the emperor with his titles of honor. There was only one answer to Jesus’ question, and it opened the way for His unexpected reply. Jesus could not be accused of disloyalty to either the Jews or the Romans. He made it clear that there are duties owed to God, but also duties to the state.
